title: A Census data feed research network
abstractText:
There is growing interest in the use of a live data feed to disseminate outputs from the 2011 Census.  Data feeds are typically used for data that may change rapidly such as news headlines, but are increasingly being used for larger more static data sets as well. 

The advantages of a data feed approach would include the ability for updates and corrections to be rapidly propagated to the user community, and for meta-data to integrated closely with the data as they are distributed.  It is hoped that easily re-usable data feeds would also promote greater use of Census data by the existing communities of researchers in a variety of public and private sector areas, by new groups of researchers, and by members of the public.

This research network will study the implications and possibilities offered by the use of a data feed to disseminate Census data.  It draws together experts from a variety of bodies including the national statistical agencies and data distributors from the academic and local government arenas.  Objectives include the assessment of competing meta-data standards, collaboration over the development of software prototypes,  delivery of specification documents, and enhanced relationships between network members.
impactText:
The work of this research network prompted ONS to set up their own working group to carry on after the end of the funding period.

The research group's ideas helped steer ONS interest in data APIs Communities and Social Services/Policy,Digital/Communication/Information Technologies (including Software),Education,Government, Democracy and Justice Policy & public services
findingsText: The funding supported a research network; the main outcomes were engagement, and cross-fertilisation of ideas, especially between researchers from different sectors (academia, local gov, national gov. The group argued strongly in support of ambitious use of data APIs by ONS The ideas are applicable not just to ONS, but to many other data providers. Communities and Social Services/Policy,Digital/Communication/Information Technologies (including Software),Education,Government, Democracy and Justice
